title: How do you restore the default value of a CSS property?
content: Use the `initial` keyword to reset a property to its default value as defined in the CSS specification.
explanation: `initial` resets a property to its browser-defined default, not inherited value.
sampleAnswers: `color: initial;` resets text color to browser default (usually black).
Unlike `inherit`, `initial` ignores parent styles and uses the spec’s default.

title: What is specificity in CSS? How is it calculated?
content: Specificity determines which CSS rule applies when multiple rules target the same element. It’s calculated based on selector types: inline styles > IDs > classes/attributes/pseudo-classes > elements.
explanation: Specificity is calculated as (inline, ID, class, element). `!important` overrides all.

title: What are CSS transitions?
content: CSS transitions allow smooth animation between two states of an element (e.g., hover). Controlled by `transition-property`, `duration`, `timing-function`, and `delay`.
explanation: Transitions require a state change (e.g., `:hover`) and only animate between defined values.
sampleAnswers: `transition: all 0.3s ease-in-out;` smoothly animates any property change over 300ms.
Transitions are ideal for micro-interactions like button hovers or menu reveals.

title: What are CSS filters?
content: CSS filters apply graphical effects like blur, brightness, or grayscale to elements using functions like `blur()`, `grayscale()`, and `drop-shadow()`.
explanation: Filters are commonly used for image adjustments, hover effects, and visual enhancements.

title: List common font-related CSS properties.
content: Key font properties: `font-family`, `font-size`, `font-weight`, `font-style`, `font-variant`, `line-height`, and system fonts like `caption`, `menu`.
explanation: These properties control typeface, size, weight, style, and spacing of text.

options.text: Fonts cannot be styled with CSS

title: List common background-related CSS properties.
content: Background properties: `background-color`, `background-image`, `background-repeat`, `background-position`, `background-size`, `background-attachment`, `background-origin`, `background-clip`.
explanation: These properties control how backgrounds are displayed, repeated, and sized.

options.text: Backgrounds are handled only by HTML

title: What is the difference between `em` and `rem` units?
content: `em` is relative to the parent’s font-size; `rem` is relative to the root (`<html>`) font-size.
explanation: `rem` avoids compounding issues in nested elements; `em` is useful for component-relative scaling.
sampleAnswers: `1em = parent font-size`; `1rem = root font-size` (usually 16px). Use `rem` for consistent spacing across components.
Nested `em` values compound (e.g., 1.5em inside 1.5em = 2.25x), while `rem` stays predictable.

title: What does `!important` mean in CSS?
content: `!important` overrides the normal cascade and specificity rules, giving the declaration the highest priority.
explanation: Avoid `!important`—it breaks maintainability and makes debugging harder. Use higher-specificity selectors instead.
sampleAnswers: `color: red !important;` will override even inline styles or ID selectors.
It should only be used in utility classes or third-party overrides as a last resort.

title: Does style2.css have to be downloaded before Paragraph 1 is rendered?
content: No. Browsers render content as it’s parsed. `<link>` in `<body>` doesn’t block rendering of prior content.
explanation: Only `<link>` in `<head>` blocks rendering. Stylesheets in `<body>` load asynchronously for subsequent content.

title: Do stylesheets block each other during download?
content: No. Modern browsers download multiple CSS files in parallel.
explanation: Browsers fetch all linked stylesheets concurrently, improving load performance.

title: What are the CSS positioning values?
content: Position values: `static` (default), `relative`, `absolute`, `fixed`, `sticky`.
explanation: Each value controls how an element is placed in the document flow and relative to other elements.

title: What is the difference between padding and margin?
content: Padding is inside the border (affects background); margin is outside the border (creates space between elements).
explanation: Margin can collapse vertically; padding cannot. Padding increases element size; margin does not.
sampleAnswers: Padding is space inside the border (background shows through); margin is space outside (transparent, no background).
Vertical margins collapse; padding never collapses and always adds to element dimensions.

title: What are CSS gradients?
content: CSS gradients are images created with `linear-gradient()`, `radial-gradient()`, or `conic-gradient()` functions.
explanation: Gradients are treated as background images and can be used anywhere an image is valid.

title: What is CSS opacity?
content: `opacity` sets the transparency of an element (0 = fully transparent, 1 = fully opaque).
explanation: Opacity affects the entire element and its children. Use `rgba()` for text-only transparency.
sampleAnswers: `opacity: 0.5;` makes an element 50% transparent, including all child content.
For text-only transparency, use `color: rgba(0,0,0,0.5);` instead of `opacity`.

title: How is inheritance applied in CSS?
content: Inheritance passes property values from parent to child elements (e.g., `color`, `font-family`). Not all properties inherit (e.g., `margin`, `padding`).
explanation: Inherited properties can be overridden. Use `inherit` to force inheritance for non-inherited properties.
sampleAnswers: Text properties like `color` and `font-family` inherit by default; layout properties like `width` do not.
Use `color: inherit;` to explicitly inherit a non-inherited property from the parent.

title: How do you handle browser differences in CSS?
content: Use `@supports` for feature detection, Autoprefixer for vendor prefixes, and graceful degradation for unsupported features.
explanation: `@supports` allows safe usage of modern features with fallbacks for older browsers.
sampleAnswers: `@supports (display: grid) { ... }` applies grid layout only if supported; otherwise, use floats or flexbox as fallback.
Combine `@supports` with `caniuse.com` data and Autoprefixer for robust cross-browser support.

title: What is the CSS cascade?
content: The cascade is the algorithm that resolves conflicting CSS rules by considering origin, importance (`!important`), specificity, and order.
explanation: The cascade ensures predictable styling by applying rules in a defined priority order.
sampleAnswers: The cascade resolves conflicts using: 1) `!important`, 2) origin (user vs author), 3) specificity, 4) source order.
Without the cascade, overlapping rules would cause unpredictable styling behavior.

title: What are CSS vendor prefixes?
content: Vendor prefixes (`-webkit-`, `-moz-`, `-ms-`, `-o-`) provide experimental or non-standard CSS properties in specific browsers.
explanation: Modern tooling like Autoprefixer adds prefixes automatically based on browser support targets.

options.text: Vendor prefixes are no longer needed
All browsers use the same prefix
Prefixes are part of the official CSS spec

title: How is the DOM linked to CSS?
content: CSS styles the DOM tree. The browser combines HTML (DOM) and CSS (CSSOM) into a render tree to display the page.
explanation: The browser parses HTML into DOM, CSS into CSSOM, combines them into a render tree, then paints the pixels.
sampleAnswers: CSS selectors target DOM nodes. The browser builds a render tree from DOM + CSSOM, then calculates layout and paints pixels.
JavaScript can manipulate both DOM (structure) and CSSOM (styles) to dynamically update the UI.

title: Explain the `table-layout` property.
content: `table-layout: auto` (default) sizes columns based on content; `table-layout: fixed` sizes columns based on table/col width, improving performance.
explanation: `fixed` layout renders faster because the browser doesn’t wait for all content to calculate column widths.
sampleAnswers: `table-layout: fixed;` uses the first row or `<col>` widths to set column sizes, ignoring cell content—great for large tables.
With `fixed`, the table renders immediately without waiting for all data, improving perceived performance.
